Hearing.paragraph: No, I get it.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: In fact, that has happened.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: Let me ask you just about this phone booth, because it is a metaphor. Are you aware that at the EPA headquarters there are two secure facilities where private phone calls could be secure?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: And, again, I didn't request a SCIF. I requested a secure communication that was not accessible to my office and----
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: I understand that. But you are the boss. So you tell your folks that you want a secure way of communicating, reasonable request, they are going to accommodate it. The boss is the one who has to make certain that it is a reasonable imposition on taxpayers, or do you disagree with that?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: And in this instance the process failed. As I indicated in my opening statement, those processes will be changed going forward.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: Did you ask the question--here is the question that I think a lot of people would ask, Republican or Democrat, how can I make a secure phone call, and the answer would be well, Mr. Pruitt, there happens to be two places in this building right close to your office where you can do that. Had you asked that----
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: They are not right close to my office.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: Pardon me?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: They are not right close to my office.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: Well, how often do you have to use your secret phone booth?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: It is for confidential communications, and it is rare.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: OK. So on those rare occasions, is it too much to ask you to walk whatever distance it takes for you to get to that secure line?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I guess it depends on the nature of the call and how urgent the call is.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: The point is that you have two locations that you can go to when you have to make those rare secure phone calls. This is taxpayer money. It is taxpayer money. Let me ask you this. Did you have installed or were there installed biometric locks on your office?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: There were problems with locks on two of the three doors and changes were made to those locks. No instruction was given for biometric locks, but that was a decision made by those individuals.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: So these things just happen.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: There was a process at the Agency in that regard, and there was an evaluation.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: Well, what is a biometric lock?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I am not entirely sure.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: So do you know, is it the case you don't know how to open your door?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I just know how to put a code in. Excuse me?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: No, seriously. What is a biometric lock?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I don't know. I just put a code in.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: A biometric lock, it responds, as I understand it, to like fingerprints or some other--your eyes, some physical characteristic.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: That is my understanding as well.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: All right, so you have them, right?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: Those are on, those have been added to the office, yes.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Welch
Hearing.paragraph: Why?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Shimkus
Hearing.paragraph: The gentleman's time has expired. The Chair recognizes the gentleman from Iowa for 5 minutes, Mr. Loebsack.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you for allowing me to waive on to this subcommittee. I do appreciate that.

Mr. Pruitt, I share a lot of the concerns my colleagues have voiced today on the ethics front, but I am actually here to talk about an issue that, as you might imagine, I am from Iowa, so of utmost importance to my State, to my district. During your confirmation process you stated that you would work to uphold the Renewable Fuel Standard and over the last 2 years President Trump has pledged on numerous occasions to support the RFS, in fact time and time again he has pledged to support it. However, over the last several weeks, information has been revealed that makes me question that commitment as you might imagine.

Various reports have indicated that the EPA has granted so- called economic hardship exemptions to numerous refiners who appear to be neither small nor financially distressed. You know what the law says, it has to be 75,000 gallons or less to be granted that economic hardship waiver. I can tell you I have heard directly from my constituents, farmers and many others, and from farmers across the country who are extremely troubled by this action. And this comes at a particularly difficult time in farm country as you know when we have had low prices, we have seen farm income trending downward, and industry profits are soaring.

I am extremely disappointed in the action as you might imagine and the lack of transparency and accountability in the process is also unacceptable. Under section 211 of the Clean Air Act, the EPA Administrator is required to reassign gallons that are waived under the small refinery exemption to other obligated parties. Because this entire waiver process has happened, really, without any transparency whatsoever, I am disappointed, my constituents are disappointed, and we really have no idea whether those gallons have been reassigned as required by law.
So my first question, Mr. Pruitt, yes or no, have you reassigned these gallons as required by law?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: It is my understanding that the process has happened as it is supposed to under the statute.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Well, we are going to need that. And how do you plan to reassign then the gallons you waive for going forward for the 2019 RVO?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: And I do think your question is very important with respect to the volume obligation, Congressman. And when you think about the commitment of this administration to the RFS, the point of obligation was denied as you know. That was a big issue.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: But that is not my point. I am talking about the waivers.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: No, I know. I understand.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: And I would like to move on to my next question if I could. Yes or no, do you intend to inform this committee and the public about the details behind these waivers such as which refiners received a waiver?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: Subject to the confidential business information or other information that would be the only thing that would not be available.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Well, Mr. Pruitt, we just want to know who got these waivers, not why necessarily, and I can't understand why that would be considered confidential business information. Reports have indicated that 25 refiners received waivers from their obligations. Is that number accurate?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: That was actually in 2017, I think. The applications are still pending in 2018.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: What is the number at the moment?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: It is over that number for 2018, as I understand it.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Did you discuss these exemptions with the White House?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: There is ongoing discussions with the White House on various issues around the RFS program.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Who at the White House specifically was involved?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I think the NEC in consultation with the Air Office.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Did you brief the President on these waivers?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: Well, as I indicated this was a dialogue amongst staff members, NEC and Air Office, at our shop. So.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Has anybody explained to the President the substantial impact that these waivers have on the ethanol industry? Some have estimated a billion gallons.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I am sure it has come up in many discussions.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: And moving on, you told me and many others that EPA is studying whether it has the legal authority to grant the RVP waiver. That was the last time that I waived on to this committee and we talked about that issue. And that seems like it is taking quite a while as you might imagine for many of us in corn country, and with the President's recent remarks which were referenced here about his interest in year- around E15, I am wondering what the holdup is on this at this point.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: It is just trying to ensure that the legal basis is solid because there will be litigation that will ensue.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Well, do you plan to move forward and grant the RVP waiver and allow year-round sales of E15?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I intend to finish that process very soon to make----
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Loebsack
Hearing.paragraph: Yes. Hopefully, the sooner the better because this is something that obviously is very important not only to my State and my district, many folks around the country. So we are looking forward to that. And of course refinery executives have called your action on the hardship waivers, to go back to that, quote, ``giving out trick-or-treat candy,'' unquote, to their industry. And I am here to tell you that farmers are very disappointed by this. They have been waiting for years for the E15 waiver year-round.

And, Mr. Chairman, I think this program is in need of substantial oversight, the waiver program and certainly the E15 as well. And these actions I don't think can happen in secret. I know that was addressed earlier in this hearing. We need to make sure that these waivers are not abused as a financial windfall for special interests and I look forward to working with you, Mr. Chairman, on this further. And I yield back. Thank you very much.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Shimkus
Hearing.paragraph: The gentleman yields back his time. The Chair recognizes the gentleman from New Mexico, Mr. Lujan, for 5 minutes.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

Administrator Pruitt, you seem to view the EPA budget as a personal slush fund, redirecting resources to your personal travel that should go to environmental protection. During your tenure you have spent more than $160,000 on travel in first class, on private jets, and on military craft. Public office is a public trust and I think flying coach is the least we can do to deserve that trust.
My question for you is this. When you are paying for your own airfare with personal funds do you fly coach?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I follow the security recommendations of my team when I pay for it personally as well.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Will you commit to reimbursing taxpayers for your luxury travel?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: You refer to it as luxury travel, and the $160,000 that you refer to pales in comparison to the previous administrations. I think you are referring to international travel. I took two international trips. Previous administrations took multiple trips and spent far more than that. These decisions about security detail, who attends and what they do to provide protection, happened according to law enforcement recommendations and that is what I followed.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: It has been recently reported by EPA ethics officials that on at least two personal trips you flew in coach on Southwest Airlines using a companion pass from Ken Wagner, your subordinate at the EPA. Clearly a plane ticket has more than nominal value. Are you aware that Federal ethics rules prohibit you from accepting gifts from subordinates?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: And that is not represented accurately, what you said. We actually flew like carpooling. We shared costs from Oklahoma----
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Did Ken Wagner give you the boarding pass?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: There was no gift whatsoever.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: All right, well, I think that those ethics officials will continue to look into that.

Mr. Pruitt, your travel since becoming Administrator has taken you to Morocco, Italy, and to luxury resorts around the United States. We have even heard from Kevin, a political appointee who worked in your office, that you told staffers to, quote, ``find me something to do,'' close quote, in order to schedule travel to your desired destinations. Unfortunately, it seems your desired destinations have rarely included low-income communities and communities of color facing serious environmental risks.

The biggest problem with the pay-to-play system is that those most at risk are also the most unable to pay for your attention and concern. Of your extensive travel spending, how much would you say you spend visiting low-income communities and communities of color?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I would consider East Chicago--which I have made trips there, I was in Region 5 recently this week, and San Jacinto in Houston, as indicated earlier. The trip to Italy was a G7 trip occurring a week after the Paris decision. I was there for 4 days around the G7. There is a free trade agreement that is in existence in Morocco, and the ambassador of Morocco invited me to Morocco to negotiate the environmental chapter on that free trade agreement. Both of those things are very important to the scope of our duties at the EPA.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Mr. Administrator, you have gone to great lengths to keep your calendar secret, but what has come out is it is clear that most of your meetings and stakeholders have been with industry and not impacted communities. I think we can agree with that. Do you see the problem with granting greater access to polluting industries than impacted communities?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I have met with stakeholders across the country on these issues, people that we regulate that their voices have not been heard for many years. Those farmers and ranchers that I have met with, they are our first environmentalists and first conservationists.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Do you understand that you have a responsibility to protect the health and environment of low-income, minority, tribal, and indigenous communities?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: Absolutely.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Throughout your brief tenure as EPA Administrator you have directed significant policy changes made with disproportionate harm to low-income, minority, Tribal, and indigenous communities. The repeal of the once-in, always-in policy mentioned by my colleague, Ms. Dingell, for example, the weakening of coal ash regulations is another. But Mr. Pruitt, today you repeatedly blamed your chief of staff, your chief counsel, career officials, and others. Yes or no, are you the EPA Administrator?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I said that in my opening statement, Congressman. And I didn't blame anyone. I just simply shared facts with you as----
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Mr. Administrator, it is just a simple yes-or-no question, sir. Are you the EPA Administrator?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I said in my opening statement that I take responsibility. I have made changes historically and making changes going forward, and I simply have not failed to take responsibility. I have simply recited the facts of what has occurred.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: It is a simple question, Mr. Pruitt. Are you the EPA Administrator?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: Yes.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Just to be clear, do you run the EPA?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I do.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Yes or no, are you responsible for the many, many scandals plaguing the EPA?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: I have responded to many of those questions here today with facts and information.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: Are you able to answer that in yes or no?
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: That is not a yes-or-no answer, Congressman.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: It is pretty simple that it is a yes-or-no answer here. There is clear concern with what has been happening not just by the entire Congress. And I appreciate you being here today, but these questions need to be asked and answered.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Pruitt
Hearing.paragraph: And we have answered them today.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Lujan
Hearing.paragraph: And you are not the only one that has been doing these ugly things, these horrific things, these scandal-plagued things in this administration, and I hope this is one of many hearings that this committee will have so we can get to the bottom of this and make sure taxpayers are made whole.
Hearing.speaker: Mr. Shimkus
Hearing.paragraph: The gentleman's has expired.

Seeing there are no further Members wishing to ask questions, I would like to thank our witness for being here today. Before we conclude, I would like to ask unanimous consent to submit the following documents for the record. I just want to make sure I get them all in: letter to the chairman and ranking member from Lauren Atkins; report from GAO on EPA's use of fiscal year 2017 appropriations; letter from the American Association for the Advancement of Science; Mr. Rush Holt; article from the Roanoke Times; questions from Ms. Castor; letter from the American Geophysical Union; letter from 985 scientists.

In pursuant to committee rules, I remind Members that they have 10 business days to submit additional questions for the record, and I ask that witnesses submit their questions within 10 business days upon receipt of the questions.
Without objection, the subcommittee is adjourned.
[Whereupon, at 1:41 p.m., the subcommittee was adjourned.]
